awd_titl_txt: Building a 1+3-Year High School to College Pathway to Prepare Students for High-demand Jobs in Information Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to create pathways for high school students to pursue training that leads to a Bachelor of Applied Science in Information Technology (IT) from Seattle community colleges, thus preparing the students for high-demand IT jobs. The pathways will enable high school students to earn up to one year of college credit toward the degree. As a result, it will be possible for them to complete their degrees in just three years after transfer to college. This project has the potential to demonstrate how coordination between high schools and community colleges with Bachelor of Applied Science programs in technical fields can help students embark and persist on pathways toward high paying careers. The project addresses the national need for a trained workforce for high demand jobs in areas such as Applications Development, Cyber Security, IT Networking and Data Analytics, while also diversifying the workforce. 

The project will pursue two primary goals: 1) Create an IT 1+3 Pathway, and 2) Recruit students into the IT 1+3 Pathway by launching an IT Academy at two Seattle Public High Schools with high populations of lower-income students. To achieve the first goal, the three community colleges within the Seattle Colleges District will align foundational college IT courses with high school dual credit IT curriculum, and work with high schools to chart the IT 1+3 pathway. To achieve the second goal, a community-based organization, Computing for All, will assist with community outreach to students and their parents/guardians to ensure the pathway serves a diverse cohort of students, including students from groups that are underrepresented in IT fields. An onboarding class will help students learn about IT careers while they build the skills needed to successfully pursue the IT degree. The partnering institutions will provide extensive support to students in the IT Academies. The support will include mentoring, tutoring, and field trips to help the students succeed in the academy and transition seamlessly to bachelor-degree pathways at local community colleges upon high school graduation. The City of Seattle will inform and advise the project to address digital equity issues for students and communities. A Technical Advisory Committee representing small, mid-size, and large IT companies in the region will inform the work of the IT 1+3 Project, ensuring it is responsive to the enormous need for qualified IT professionals in the region. The evaluation plan will include quantitative and qualitative measures to assess the project's impact on students, faculty, and schools. Once the IT 1+3 pathway is established, the project includes a plan to sustain the pathway through the normal operations of both the high schools and the colleges. The IT 1+3 Project builds on other NSF and ATE projects that are developing pathways to Bachelor of Applied Science degrees in Washington State, with the potential to result in a sustainable and replicable model for similar high school to college pipelines in IT and other technical fields.  This project is funded by the NSF Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Building a 1+3-Year High School to College Pathway to Prepare Students for High-demand Jobs in Information Technology Project aimed to expand dual-credit opportunities beyond traditional K-12 systems to communities supporting opportunity youth, out-of-school youth, and in-school youth. 

Providing opportunities for underrepresented youth in IT fields aligns with the mission and values of Seattle Colleges. While engaging BIPoC youth, the project addresses critical equity needs across industry, society, and higher education. The project was founded on the premise of articulated dual-credit for high school students and an accelerated pathway to high-demand, high-wage careers in the “fastest growing technology hub in the nation”.   

During the project's onset, Seattle Colleges acknowledged local school districts' challenges in meeting the accelerated pathway (dual-credit) demands within the regional IT framework. Factors such as curriculum and course development, alongside employing qualified CTE faculty, influenced the project's initial success. These challenges were exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading Seattle Colleges to pivot from awarding high school articulated dual credit to collaborating exclusively with Computing for All (C4A), a nonprofit focused on preparing underrepresented individuals for equitable, upwardly mobile IT careers. This deviation was instrumental in successfully expanding the reach to students who otherwise would have been excluded.

Broader Impacts

Through this initiative, C4A developed pathways in full-stack software development to feed into Seattle Colleges' IT programs, boot camps, and pre-apprenticeships. Together, Seattle Colleges and C4A designed a project model to map Seattle Colleges’ foundational IT courses to C4A’s IT pathway, resulting in a dual-credit crosswalk. Completion assessments that align with college standards provide documentation for knowledge and skills acquired through non-college training. 

Eligible students who finish C4A coursework earn completion badges, which they can use at their discretion (e.g., LinkedIn profile, resume, social media). Dual credit is transcribed when students enroll at Seattle Colleges and present their badge. 

Throughout the project's duration, stakeholders highlighted the dynamic and evolving nature of the regional IT industry. This compelled IT faculty across Seattle Colleges to work on curricular alignment to establish a core IT curriculum for both Seattle Colleges and Washington state. The IT Center of Excellence and C4A gathered partners like Amazon, F5, Microsoft, Snowflake, and Google to pinpoint key focus areas within the IT ecosystem, including Data Science/Analytics, Software Development, Cloud/Systems Administration, and Cybersecurity. 

Seattle Colleges established a District-wide IT Technical Advisory Board to review the curriculum. The objectives of this initiative were to: 

  • Assist faculty in identifying and categorizing content across the District. 
  • Evaluate and update current content as necessary. 
  • Standardize and revise pathways throughout the District. 
  • Develop new pathways in collaboration with the Centers of Excellence. 
  • Create and promote cohesive IT programs (IT ED North, IT ED South, IT ED Central). 

Over the life of the grant, the project team has collaborated with various esteemed partners to underscore the project's value. These partners include the League for Innovation, the Washington Technology Alliance, the Center for Excellence in IT, and the Workforce Education Council. Additionally, the team has established connections with representatives from regional organizations to further advance the pathway. 

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2024
Modified by: Chris Sullivan

Providing opportunities for underrepresented youth in IT fields aligns with the mission and values of Seattle Colleges.
